1.QUESTION: These factors do not influence the width of a confidence interval in descriptive studies except

OPTION.C: The variance of the variable under study
OPTION.E: The standard deviation of the variable under study

1.EXPLANATION: The width of a confidence interval depends on the significance level, sample size, variance, and standard deviation. Power is relevant for hypothesis testing, not CI width.

2.QUESTION: When comparing the sample means with the use of a t-test, which of the following conditions should be satisfied?

OPTION.A: The two samples must have been selected through a probability method of sampling
OPTION.B: At least one of the samples must be smaller or equal to 30
OPTION.C: The two sample variances must be equal
OPTION.D: The variable under study may have a binomial distribution
OPTION.E: The sample sizes drawn from these populations must be equal

2.EXPLANATION: T-tests assume samples are randomly selected and variances are equal (for independent t-test). Sample size equality and distribution type are not strict requirements.

3.QUESTION: The following statement is not true about sampling

OPTION.A: The unit of enquiry is always the same as the sampling unit
OPTION.B: Proportional allocation is usually applied when selecting a simple random sample
OPTION.C: The sampling fraction is the ratio of sample size to the population size

3.EXPLANATION: The unit of enquiry may differ from the sampling unit. Proportional allocation is usually applied in stratified sampling, not simple random sampling.

4.QUESTION: The following cannot be classified as nominal variables

OPTION.A: Presence or absence of blood in sputum
OPTION.C: Histological type of tumor

4.EXPLANATION: Nominal variables are categorical. Presence/absence is binary (dichotomous), not nominal in classical sense; ICD codes, histological type, and race are nominal.

5.QUESTION: The following statements about the mean of a large sample size (n) are correct

OPTION.A: It is always greater than the median
OPTION.B: It is calculated using the formula Σx/n
OPTION.C: It estimates the population mean with less precision than the mean of a small sample
OPTION.D: Increases as the sample size increases
OPTION.E: It is always greater than the standard deviation

5.EXPLANATION: The mean is calculated as Σx/n. It is not always greater than the median or SD, and larger samples estimate population mean with greater precision.

6.QUESTION: Which of the following statements about the histogram are true

OPTION.A: Usually shows the development of quality over time
OPTION.B: Could be used to show the distribution of lengths of stay in patients admitted with acute asthma
OPTION.C: Could be used to show the distribution of birth weights in a sample of babies
OPTION.D: Conveys information about the spread of a distribution
OPTION.E: It is the best way to show relationship between weight and blood pressure

6.EXPLANATION: Histograms show distribution and spread of a single variable. Time trends or relationships between two variables require line charts or scatterplots.

7.QUESTION: The following can be said to be true about population pyramids

OPTION.A: The oldest age group is open ended
OPTION.B: Females are represented on the left and males on the right side of the pyramid
OPTION.C: Age is represented on the horizontal axis
OPTION.D: Age data is commonly categorized into 5 or 10 years age groups
OPTION.E: Its base is broad in population of most third world countries

7.EXPLANATION: Males are usually on the left, age on vertical axis, oldest group often open-ended, and developing countries have broad bases.

8.QUESTION: Management by objectives includes all except

OPTION.B: How much is to be done?
OPTION.C: Where it is to be done?
OPTION.D: When it is to be completed?
OPTION.E: Which standard it will be done

8.EXPLANATION: Management by objectives focuses on goals, quantity, timeline, and standards, but not on the physical location.

9.QUESTION: The following are the skills of an effective manager

OPTION.C: Scientific skill

9.EXPLANATION: Effective managers need human, technical, and conceptual skills. Scientific and technological skills are not core managerial skills.

10.QUESTION: An ideal health indicator should have the following qualities

OPTION.C: Probability

10.EXPLANATION: Health indicators should be valid, sensitive, and feasible. Probability and turbidity are not qualities of indicators.

11.QUESTION: Which of these is/are risk(s) associated with medical wastes

OPTION.C: Public nuisance (offensive smells, unsightly debris)

11.EXPLANATION: Medical waste poses multiple risks including injuries, infections, environmental harm, and public nuisance.

12.QUESTION: Which of the following definitions is/ are correct

OPTION.A: Sewage - household waste not containing faeces
OPTION.B: Sullage - network of sewers from the same area that discharges into a common pool
OPTION.C: Sewer - waste water from kitchen, bathrooms, laundry, etc
OPTION.D: Sewerage - connection pipes that take away faeces from the toilet
OPTION.E: Sullarage - connection of pipes that take away household waste without faeces

12.EXPLANATION: Sewage contains faeces. Sullage is wastewater from kitchens and baths. Sewerage is the pipe system for faecal removal.

13.QUESTION: These are biological consequences of poor refuse disposal

OPTION.C: Infestation with rats and vermins

13.EXPLANATION: Poor refuse disposal leads to vermin infestation, pollution, and bad odors. HIV/AIDS is not transmitted by flies; space occupying is not a biological consequence.

14.QUESTION: These are not social components of the environment

OPTION.C: Political systems

14.EXPLANATION: Social components include morals, customs, political and economic systems. Health systems are structural, not social components.

15.QUESTION: The following events can affect environmental temperatures, causing global warming

OPTION.C: Eclipse of the moon

15.EXPLANATION: Desertification, urbanization, and deforestation contribute to global warming. Reforestation reduces warming; lunar eclipses do not affect climate.

16.QUESTION: The following are formal sources of literature in research

OPTION.C: Search engines - Google

16.EXPLANATION: Formal sources include journals, books, official reports, PubMed, theses. Search engines like Google are not formal literature sources.

17.QUESTION: Ethical issues in research involves which of the following

OPTION.C: Reasons for the study
OPTION.D: Permission for access to medical records

17.EXPLANATION: Ethical issues focus on consent, withdrawal rights, access permissions, and results sharing. Reason for study is not an ethical requirement.

18.QUESTION: The following are quantitative methods of data collection except

OPTION.C: Observational Checklists

18.EXPLANATION: Quantitative methods include structured questionnaires, data sheets, checklists, and case notes. Key informant interviews are qualitative.

19.QUESTION: Which of the following statements concerning community participation is true

OPTION.A: The community is involved only in the implementation of health programs
OPTION.B: The community should be involved in planning, implementation and evaluation
OPTION.C: The community should be involved in the funding of health programs

19.EXPLANATION: Effective community participation includes involvement in planning, implementation, and evaluation. Funding is not a primary requirement.

20.QUESTION: Concerning the sick role

OPTION.A: Roles are delegated or socially adjusted
OPTION.B: Sick role is the same as patient role
OPTION.C: Assumption of the sick role may lead to social crisis
OPTION.D: The uncooperative patient is labeled as malingering
OPTION.E: The patient is to be held responsible for his sickness

20.EXPLANATION: The sick role involves social adjustments and possible stigma. It differs from patient role and patients are not blamed for illness.

21.QUESTION: Incidence

OPTION.A: Is used as a health status indicator
OPTION.C: Is used to determine the magnitude of new cases
OPTION.E: All of the above is true

21.EXPLANATION: Incidence measures new cases over a period, expressed as a ratio. It is distinct from prevalence.

22.QUESTION: Concerning Zika virus

OPTION.A: Many people infected with Zika virus won't have symptoms
OPTION.B: There is no specific medicine for Zika
OPTION.C: Some people infected with Zika virus will only have mild symptoms
OPTION.D: The most common symptoms of Zika are fever, rash, joint pain, or conjunctivitis
OPTION.E: The illness is usually mild with symptoms lasting for a few days to a week

22.EXPLANATION: Zika virus infections are often asymptomatic or mild; treatment is supportive.

23.QUESTION: Concerning Lassa fever

OPTION.B: Early supportive care with rehydration and symptomatic treatment improves survival
OPTION.C: About 80% of people who become infected with Lassa virus have no symptoms
OPTION.D: Lassa fever is a zoonotic disease
OPTION.E: On rare occasions, travellers from areas where Lassa fever is endemic export the disease to other countries

23.EXPLANATION: Lassa fever is mostly asymptomatic, zoonotic, treatable with supportive care; case-fatality is higher than 1% in hospitalized cases.

24.QUESTION: Confirmation that symptoms are caused by Ebola virus infection are made using the following investigations

OPTION.C: Reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay

24.EXPLANATION: Ebola is diagnosed with ELISA, antigen detection, and RT-PCR. Light microscopy and bacterial culture are not applicable.

25.QUESTION: The following statements about sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are true except

OPTION.A: They are only transmitted through sexual contacts
OPTION.B: Chlamydia trachomatis is a bacterial STI
OPTION.C: Incidence can be increased by greater availability of forms of contraception
OPTION.D: Soiled fomites may transmit vulvo-vaginitis to pre-pubescent girls
OPTION.E: Early diagnosis and treatment is not an important control measure

25.EXPLANATION: STIs can be transmitted non-sexually in rare cases; early diagnosis and treatment are important control measures.
